newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakhstan to auction 2-yr T-bills from June 30.
newsitem.headline: Kazakhstan to auction 2-yr T-bills from June 30.

text.p: Kazakhstan will start auctioning two-year Treasury bills from June 30, with full access to non-residents, Deputy Finance Minister Sauat Mynbayev said on Friday.

"We think the time is ready to introduce longer-term paper and we will start with two-year bills," Mynbayev told a news conference. He said the first monthly auction would take place on June 30. "The volume will be about 200 million tenge ($2.6 million)," he said.
Mynbayev said the yield would be around 20 percent to be paid twice a year. The former Soviet republic already issues three-month, six-month and 12-month MKM bills.

"Slowly the market is moving to the longer term and yields are falling," Mynbayev said. The average yield on three-month MKM discount treasury bills rose slightly this week to 10.97 at auction on June 17 from 10.64 the previous week.

But overall, yields have halved in recent weeks, driving domestic banks out of the market -- annual inflation for this year is officially reckoned at 17 percent -- while foreign investors have turned to other markets to shop for better returns.

Country risk for longer term paper is also a factor for foreign buyers, according to ABN AMRO Bank Kazakhstan's chief treasurer, Oleg Tsurkan. "About half my foreign clients say one year and no more," he said.
